Package com.augursystems.armi

Class Armi

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.augursystems.armi.Armi
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable
    public final class Armi
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable
    The ARMI server orchestrates all communication to/from any number of remote ARMI servers and the local clients/listeners. The ARMI protocol/implementation is an alternative to RMI, with the addition of asynchronous one-to-many messaging via a publish/subscribe mechanism.

    This Armi class is your main interface for registering "services", calling methods on services, subscribing for asynchronous data, and publishing data. To get started, you need an instance of Armi. Usually, you only need one per JVM. With this Armi instance, you can use the call() method to execute methods on a local or remote service, or subscribe for data on a local or remote ARMI server.

    If you want to register a server for remote callers, or publish data for remote subscribers, you first need to call acceptRemoteClients(). That will start a server socket listening for remote requests. Then you can call registerService() or use publish(), respectively.

    An instance of any class that has public methods with Serializable parameters and Serializable return value can be registered as a 'service'.

    Note: The 'runnable' and 'ss' variables aren't fully protected for thread safety yet, although realistically they are quite safe for normal usage.

      • isRunnable

        public final boolean isRunnable()
        Returns:
        A boolean indicating the state of the remote client listener (when hosting remotely accessible services); only TRUE after acceptRemoteClients() is called, and until shutdown() is called.

      • run

        public final void run()
        Accept connections from remote servers (which are proxies for their local clients)
        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable

      • join

        public final void join()
        Waits until the remote client-accepting thread finishes; used by CommandLine to make sure the JVM doesn't exit immediately, since the thread is a daemon.

      • getServiceNames

        public java.util.ArrayList<java.io.Serializable> getServiceNames()
        The List<Serializable> of service names (actually the whole list is String). Used by the "Armi" service.

      • getSubscriptionDescriptions

        public java.util.ArrayList<java.io.Serializable> getSubscriptionDescriptions()
        The List<Serializable> of subscriptions types currently tracked; actually the whole list is Strings, of the general format: "[type]/[flavor]". Used by the "Armi" service.

      • shutdown

        public final void shutdown()
        Shuts down any non-daemon threads, closes sockets, and cleans up memory. If called from main(), this should likely exit the JVM.

        Convenience method that will wrap the Serializable in an ARMI Packet and transmit to all subscribers of its type.
        Parameters:
        a - The Serializable object to transmit to all subscribers of its type.

      • publish

        public final void publish​(java.io.Serializable a,
                          java.lang.String flavor)
        Convenience method that will wrap the Serializable in an ARMI Packet and transmit to all subscribers of its type.
        Parameters:
        a - The Serializable object to transmit to all subscribers of its type.

      • publish

        public final void publish​(Packet p)
        Called by a local broadcaster, or a remote client via a Receiver. Will transmit the packet to matching flavored subscribers, and also to non-flavored subscriptions regardless of the packet's flavor.
        Parameters:
        p - The Packet to be transmitted to all subscribers of its service.

      • subscribe

        public final Subscription subscribe​(java.lang.String type,
                                    java.lang.String flavor,
                                    Filter filter,
                                    Client client,
                                    HostPort hp)
                             throws ArmiException
        Subscribe to a data type/flavor published on this and/or a remote ARMI server. Any subsequent matching data packets will be sent to the given Client.
        Parameters:
        hp - The HostPort of the remote ARMI server; null if you are only subscribing to this local Armi instance.
        type - The String 'type' of data to receive; usually this is the fully qualified class name of the object. Must not be null.
        flavor - The String 'flavor' of data to receive; null if you want all flavors.
        filter - An optionally null Filter that further limits the subscription; if the Filter is also an instance of Serializable, it is sent to the remote server so that it may prevent unnecessary transmissions over the network; in either case, the filter is always applied at the local server too.
        client - The Client implementation where matching data should be sent when published.
        Returns:
        Your Subscription receipt; hold on to it; you'll need it if you wish to cancel later.
        Throws:
        ArmiException

      • registerService

        public final void registerService​(java.lang.String name,
                                  java.lang.Object service)
                           throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Registers (or unregisters) a named service for remote method calls.
        Parameters:
        name - The published name of the server; usually the fully-qualified class name.
        service - The Object providing the service; any public method on the object is available for calls; use null if you want to unregister the named service.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException

      • call

        public final java.io.Serializable call​(HostPort hp,
                                       java.lang.String serviceName,
                                       java.lang.String method,
                                       java.io.Serializable[] args)
                                throws ArmiException
        Execute a remote method, synchronously (like RMI).
        Parameters:
        hp - The HostPort of the remote server that you want to call.
        serviceName - The String name of the service, as registered by the service on the remote server.
        method - The String method name to call on the remote service; this is the actual name of a public Java method within the service's implementing class.
        args - The Serializable[] of method arguments; may be null if the method has no parameters
        Returns:
        The Serializable value returned from the call.
        Throws:
        ArmiException - if anything goes wrong; it is usually received from the remote server. If the ArmiException.getCause() is an IOException, it usually means that there was a problem contacting the remote server. TODO: Use the time-out form of the openRemoteServer() to optionally specify a non-default time-out for callers

      • acceptRemoteClients

        public final int acceptRemoteClients()
                              throws java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                                     java.io.IOException
        A convenience method to call acceptRemoteClients() on any local network interface, at default ARMI port number
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException
        java.io.IOException

      • acceptRemoteClients

        public final int acceptRemoteClients​(HostPort hp,
                                     Armi.AccessControl control)
                              throws java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                                     java.io.IOException
        Starts a socket server to accept remote clients; until then, this Armi instance can only be used to make calls or subscribe. This call is necessary only when you want to make this ARMI server available to external clients. In other words, when you are publishing data to this ARMI server, and want to let remote ARMI clients subscribe. You should call this at most once per instance, otherwise an exception is thrown.

        If you are not publishing data to this Armi instance, then you do not need to call this method at all. You can still use this Armi instance to communicate with remote ARMI servers, as a client.

        Usually you only need one Armi instance per JVM, but multiple instances may be useful if you want to create private messaging domains.

        Parameters:
        hp - The HostPort where the socket should bind; to bind all local interfaces, use null 'host' when constructing the HostPort; to bind to a randomly available port number, use a 'port' value of zero when constructing the HostPort (useful only when this ARMI server is going to "register" itself for call-backs from a remote ARMI server).
        Returns:
        The port number where the server is running; this number is only useful when you explictly specify a zero port number since a random port number will be assigned; otherwise it just returns the same port number you specified.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the server is already running for this Armi instance.
        java.io.IOException - if there is an I/O problem starting the ServerSocket.

      • toString

        public final java.lang.String toString()
        Used for diagnostics.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        A String containing this ARMI object's unique ID, and information regarding its status as a server for remote connections.
